chunks.title: Section 302 IPC - Punishment for Murder
chunks.content: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
chunks.summary: Prescribes punishment for murder: death penalty or life imprisonment with fine.

chunks.title: Trial and Bailability
chunks.content: Murder is a cognizable, non-bailable offence triable by a Court of Session.
chunks.summary: Non-bailable, cognizable, tried by Sessions Court.

chunks.title: Ingredients of Murder
chunks.content: Murder requires intention or knowledge of likely death and actus reus causing death.
chunks.summary: Defines mental and physical elements of murder.

chunks.title: Nature of Offence
chunks.content: The offence under Section 302 IPC is classified as cognizable, meaning police can register FIR and arrest without prior magistrate approval.
chunks.summary: Cognizable offence: police can act without magistrate approval.

chunks.title: Bailability
chunks.content: Section 302 IPC is non-bailable. Bail is at the discretion of the court, not a right.

chunks.title: Trial Jurisdiction
chunks.content: Due to seriousness, Section 302 IPC offences are triable by the Court of Session.

chunks.title: Witness Testimony
chunks.content: Eyewitness accounts and corroboration are essential to establish guilt.
chunks.summary: Witness testimony with corroboration strengthens prosecution.

chunks.title: Medical & Forensic Evidence
chunks.content: Medical reports and forensic analysis establish the nature of injury, cause of death, or identity of accused.
chunks.summary: Expert medical/forensic reports crucial for proof.

chunks.title: Mens Rea & Actus Reus
chunks.content: Court assesses intention (mens rea) and the act (actus reus) together to establish liability.
chunks.summary: Both mental and physical elements required.

chunks.case_name: K.M. Nanavati v. State of Maharashtra
chunks.issue: Was it murder or culpable homicide?
chunks.ratio: Heat of passion may reduce offence.

chunks.case_name: State of Rajasthan v. Kashi Ram
chunks.ratio: Chain of evidence must be complete.

chunks.case_name: Bachan Singh v. State of Punjab
chunks.ratio: Death only in rarest of rare cases.

chunks.question: What is the punishment under Section 302 IPC?
chunks.answer: Punishment includes imprisonment and/or fine as provided by law.

chunks.question: Is Section 302 a bailable offence?
chunks.answer: No, it is generally non-bailable.

chunks.question: Is Section 302 a cognizable offence?
chunks.answer: Yes, police may register FIR and investigate without magistrate approval.

chunks.question: What is the minimum punishment for Section 302 IPC?
chunks.answer: The minimum punishment is life imprisonment; death penalty is also possible depending on the case.

chunks.question: What is the maximum punishment under Section 302 IPC?
chunks.answer: The maximum punishment is the death penalty.

chunks.question: Is Section 302 IPC compoundable?
chunks.answer: No, offences under Section 302 are not compoundable in the eyes of law.

chunks.question: Do all murders result in the death penalty under Section 302?
chunks.answer: No, the death penalty is given only in the 'rarest of rare' cases; otherwise, life imprisonment is awarded.

chunks.question: What are the essential ingredients of murder under Section 302 IPC?
chunks.answer: There must be an act of causing death, intention or knowledge to cause death, and the act must not fall under exceptions of Section 300.

chunks.question: Does Section 302 IPC require intention to kill?
chunks.answer: Yes, intention or knowledge that the act is likely to cause death is necessary for conviction.

chunks.question: Can a minor be charged under Section 302 IPC?
chunks.answer: Yes, but if the accused is under 18 years, provisions of the Juvenile Justice Act apply for trial and sentencing.

chunks.question: What is the difference between Section 300 and Section 302 IPC?
chunks.answer: Section 300 defines murder; Section 302 prescribes the punishment for murder.

chunks.question: Can Section 302 IPC be invoked for attempt to murder?
chunks.answer: No, attempt to murder is covered under Section 307 IPC, not Section 302.

chunks.question: Does a life sentence under Section 302 mean imprisonment for the convict's entire life?
chunks.answer: Yes, unless remitted or commuted as per law by appropriate government authorities; generally, life imprisonment means remainder of natural life.

chunks.question: Can Section 302 IPC cases be tried by a Magistrate?
chunks.answer: No, Section 302 offences are triable only by a Court of Session due to their seriousness.

chunks.question: Are medical reports necessary in Section 302 IPC prosecutions?
chunks.answer: Medical reports and post-mortem examination are crucial evidence to establish cause of death in murder cases.

chunks.question: What are some common defences against a charge of murder under Section 302?
chunks.answer: Common defences include absence of intention, grave and sudden provocation, private defence, alibi, unsound mind, and benefit of doubt due to insufficient evidence.

chunks.question: What is the limitation period for trial under Section 302 IPC?
chunks.answer: There is no limitation period for murder prosecutions; the case can be tried at any time after the commission of the offence.

chunks.question: Is abetment of murder punishable under Section 302 IPC?
chunks.answer: Abetment is punished under Section 109 or 120B IPC in combination with Section 302, not under Section 302 alone.

chunks.question: Do Section 302 IPC convictions affect government employment?
chunks.answer: Yes, conviction for murder (Section 302) generally disqualifies a person from government service.

chunks.question: Can a conviction under Section 302 IPC be appealed?
chunks.answer: Yes, a person convicted under Section 302 IPC can appeal to the High Court and subsequently to the Supreme Court.
